text: hi I'm Alyssa Clark from the dining
section
I'll bet by this point in the year you
probably think you've done everything
you could possibly do with root
vegetables but have you made radish
kimchi pickle crunchy this isn't a
traditional kimchi what I'm doing is
taking the flavors of kimchi and
applying it to a quickly made overnight
pickle make it today eat it tomorrow
so what I have here are radishes I've
got regular table radishes and I also
have this watermelon radish which looks
really cool if you can't find it just
use a lot of regular table radishes you
can also use breakfast radishes or if
you see them sometimes you can find
white radishes or daikon any of those
will work you want to leave the peel on
for color but you want to clean them
really well
I just scrub them with a potato brush
under cold running water and I think I
got most of this schmutz off and then I
trim the tops but I left a little bit of
the greens it's decorative it looks
really pretty and it tastes good too
then just either quarter them or have
them depending on how big your radishes
are they should be in bite-sized pieces
for the watermelon radish if you see
little bruises or imperfections on it
you might just want to take a vegetable
peeler and just peel off any place that
looks like something you wouldn't want
to eat and also you want to scrub that
really well with a potato brush under
cold running water
now just trim the top and tail and cut
it into bite-size pieces it doesn't
really matter how you cut it but if you
want it to look like a watermelon if you
want to do it in little wedges you know
just toss your radishes with some coarse
kosher salt I'm using a tablespoon and a
half for the exact recipe go to
nytimes.com slash dining and when it's
well coated just let it sit for 20
minutes while your radishes are brining
you can make the chili paste mixture so
I'm gonna grate a garlic clove you could
also mince it but I find it easier to
just grate it
and because I'm gonna be grading some
ginger I am already gonna be dirtying up
the grater so you might as well now I'm
gonna grate up some ginger I'm gonna use
about that much just about an inch fish
first thing there you want to peel your
ginger you could use a vegetable peeler
or this is a cool way to do it you could
use a spoon you just take the tip of the
spoon and run it over the ginger and the
skin comes right off ginger skin is
really thin so this is easy to do and
you just want to push the juice right
through the grater you want all that
lovely ginger juice just go like that
I'm gonna add the ginger and the garlic
to just a little bit of water
now I'm gonna stir in the crucial
ingredient for making kimchi and that is
Korean chili flakes don't use the ground
Korean chili powder that's much spicier
you want to look for these flakes then I
have got just a pinch of sugar a little
bit of sugar you could leave the chili
paste as it is it'd be delicious but if
you want that extra little umami flavor
you can add some chopped anchovies now
you just want to wash off some of the
salt that's on the radishes really
quickly under cold water save the brine
in the bowl and you're going to need it
later now I just want to coat your
radishes with the chili paste use my
hands it's just so much more efficient
once they're well coated you just want
to pack them into a jar press down on
them a little bit so you can fit in lots
in now this is a cool trick so you take
all your brining liquid that you've
saved and in order not to waste one drop
of that good chili paste take your
brining liquid pour it in to the little
bowl way this mixture chilly and then
pour this into the jar you're not gonna
have enough to fill the jar that's
perfectly fine so don't worry about it
seal the jar and don't touch it till
tomorrow that's the hard part
